ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I understood how historical fascism coopted pop culture in Italy and, through studying that relationship (which we learned comes from Antonio Gramsci's theory on popular culture), I developed a better understanding for how neofascist movements work.
Historical knowledge of Fascism and neo fascist organizations and movements, up to date critical readings, original connections among topics.

Where do I begin. Coolest class I've ever taken. Phenomenal professor. So much knowledge. Fascism, the politics of it, theories of culture, Gramsci, Adorno, Horkheimer, Mussolini's rise and fall, the partisan war, Italian nationalist politics, the far right, the far left, Trumpism, what defines an ethnicity or national identity, youth groups, film analysis - like actually everything. So good. So amazing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses at all. Extremely strong course -- targeted readings that didn't waste one's time, great teaching from Serena (who is an absolute GEM) and a really interesting topic I think.
This course is great! No improvement needed.
There are no weaknesses. Phenomenal. I mean the book was garbage for the last class but we unpacked that (My Brother is an Only Child). Never received any feedback on anything either :(

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was all on Zoom. I have no major complaints. We made the best of a regrettable situation. I don't think the course could have been better if it were different.
Wow everything succeeded. What an amazing class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. Fascism is a perennial sickness. I think everyone has an obligation to study it. This course gives one space to study it, and with great teaching too.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in 20th century history, cultural studies or Italian studies. We covered great material, making original connections. I always received feedback and the instructor allowed plenty of time for discussion
10000000% yes. No questions. Anything Serena teaches. Anything at all. This is not up for debate.
